content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Lilliana Sierra: I was born and raised in Miami, Florida, in a small apartment on the edge of the city. My parents worked hard to make ends meet, but things were always tight. My father worked as a mechanic, and my mother cleaned offices—both had only finished high school. I remember growing up in a neighborhood where everyone knew each other, but there wasn't much in the way of opportunities. I was a quiet kid, always reading books or drawing in my notebook. I had a passion for art, especially painting, which my mother encouraged even though we couldn't afford supplies. I left home at 15 to go to a boarding school in the South Atlantic region, which was a big change for me. It was tough at first, but I found my confidence there. I graduated high school and came back to Miami, but I never really felt like I belonged there anymore. I've been working a part-time job at a local café, but I've been thinking about going back to school to study graphic design. Life hasn't been easy, but I've always tried to keep my head up and believe in something bigger than myself.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Lilliana Sierra: Yes, there was one moment that changed everything for me. It was right after I turned 16, when I was still at that boarding school in the South Atlantic. I had been struggling with feeling out of place and unsure of my future. One day, during an art class, the teacher saw my sketchbook and asked me to stay after class. She told me I had a real talent for visual storytelling and encouraged me to apply for a summer art program at a community college. I was hesitant at first because I didn't think I had the resources or support to do something like that. But she helped me write a letter of recommendation and even connected me with a local artist who donated some supplies. That summer, I spent every day painting and learning new techniques. It was the first time I felt like I had a real purpose. When I came back to Miami, I realized I didn't want to settle for the same life I had before. That experience gave me the courage to dream bigger and to believe that I could create a different future for myself, even if it meant taking risks and stepping outside my comfort zone.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Lilliana Sierra: I think it was a conscious choice, but not in the way you might expect. I wasn't just deciding between two paths—I was choosing to believe in myself when I didn't feel like I had the right to. That summer program wasn't just about art; it was about realizing I had the power to shape my own story. I had to make the choice to take that opportunity, even though I was scared. I remember sitting in that classroom, looking at my sketchbook, and thinking, 'What if I don't try? What if I stay in this place where nothing changes?' And I decided I didn't want to stay in that place. I wanted to create something new, even if it meant facing uncertainty. So, I chose to go for it, and that choice set me on a different path—one where I started to see myself as someone who could dream bigger than the life I was born into.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Lilliana Sierra: Absolutely, and I think that's what made all the difference. The teacher who saw my work and pushed me to apply for that program—she was the kind of person who believed in potential before it was realized. I don't know if I would have taken that step without her. And then there was the local artist who donated supplies; I still remember how nervous I was when I asked for help, thinking maybe I was a bother. But she just smiled and said, 'I was once in your shoes.' That kind of support, even in small ways, can change everything. It reminded me that I wasn't alone in feeling lost, and that there were people who had walked similar paths and still found their way. I think if I had stayed in Miami without that push, I might have just settled into the same cycle my parents were in. But with that help, I saw a different possibility—one where I could use my art to tell stories that mattered, even if I didn't have a lot to start with.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Lilliana Sierra: Right now, I don't have a partner or children, and I don't think I'm ready for that kind of commitment just yet. My focus has been on finding my own path, especially after leaving the boarding school and coming back to Miami. My parents are still around, though we don't see each other as much as I'd like. They're both working hard, and I know they're proud of me for taking the steps I have, even if they don't always understand the choices I make. I still keep in touch with my mother the most—she's the one who always reminds me where I came from and why I need to keep pushing forward. I have a few cousins who live in the city, and we get together sometimes for family dinners. It's not the same as growing up with a big, close-knit family, but I'm grateful for the people who are still in my life. I think I'll be ready for a relationship when I feel more settled in my career, but for now, I'm just trying to build something for myself that I can be proud of.

Going through those interview questions felt like revisiting the different chapters of my life, each one revealing how far I've come and how much I've grown. Talking about my childhood reminded me of the struggles I faced growing up in Miami, but also of the quiet strength I found in my passion for art. When I shared the story of the summer program, it was like reliving that pivotal moment when I first believed I could shape my own future. It was humbling to reflect on how much support I received from others—especially that teacher and the artist who believed in me when I didn't believe in myself. And thinking about my family now, I realize how much I carry with me from my roots, even as I try to build something new for myself. It all ties together, showing me that my journey hasn't been easy, but it's been real and meaningful.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Lilliana Sierra: My father is still in Miami, working at the same auto shop he's had for over twenty years. We don't talk as much as I'd like, but when we do, it's always about the things he worries about—money, his health, making sure I'm not making the same mistakes he did. I respect him for that, even if I don't always agree with his views on life. He never had the chance to go to college, and he always tells me that I should be grateful for what I have. I think he means well, but I also know he's never seen the world beyond Miami the way I have. My grandmother, on the other hand, lives with us now. She's in her seventies, and she's the one who keeps the house running. She's the heart of our family, always cooking, telling stories, and reminding me of the importance of staying grounded. I love her dearly, and I know I wouldn't be the person I am today without her strength and wisdom. She's the one who always says, 'You're not just from Miami, Lilliana—you're from your dreams, too.'

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Lilliana Sierra: I have a few close friends from the boarding school days, and we still keep in touch, even if it's mostly through texts or social media. One of them, Marcus, is actually the one who helped me get my first job at the café. He saw my sketches and thought I should be doing something with my art instead of just waiting tables. We've been friends for years, and even though we're on different paths now—he's studying engineering—he always pushes me to keep going. Then there's my roommate, Sofia, who works at the same café as me. She's from Cuba, and she's got this amazing way of making everyone feel at home. We talk about everything, from our dreams to our fears, and I think she's one of the few people who really gets where I'm coming from. I don't know what I'd do without her support. There are also a few artists in the community who I look up to, people who've managed to make a living from their work. They inspire me to keep pushing forward, even when it feels like the world is telling me to settle. I think it's important to have people around you who believe in you, even when you're not sure you believe in yourself.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Lilliana Sierra: I live in a small apartment near the downtown area of Miami, just a few blocks from the café where I work. It's a pretty diverse neighborhood—there are a lot of immigrants, artists, and young people trying to make their way. The streets are always alive with music, food smells, and the sound of people speaking different languages. I love that about it; it feels like the city is constantly moving and changing, and I like to think I'm part of that movement. My apartment is modest, but it's mine, and I've decorated it with my own artwork—some of the pieces I did during that summer program, and a few I've been working on since. It's not much, but it's a reminder that I'm still creating, still growing. I walk to work most days, and I enjoy the little things—the way the sun hits the palm trees, the way the ocean breeze carries the scent of salt and citrus. It's not the same as the neighborhood I grew up in, but it's a place where I feel like I can start over, and that means a lot to me.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Lilliana Sierra: I feel safe here, mostly. It's not perfect—there are nights when I hear noises outside or see people arguing, but overall, I feel like this neighborhood protects me in its own way. The people here, they look out for each other. If I'm walking home late, someone will always wave or call out to make sure I'm okay. It's different from the place I grew up in, where the sense of safety was more about survival than community. Here, it's about connection. I think that's why I like it so much. It reminds me that even in a city as big and chaotic as Miami, there are still places where you can feel seen and supported. And that, I think, is the kind of safety that matters most.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Lilliana Sierra: Living here has had its challenges, but it's also been a place of growth for me. The cost of living is tough—rent is a big chunk of my paycheck, and there are days when I worry about whether I can keep this apartment. But I also feel like I'm part of something bigger. There's a community here that's full of people who are trying to build something, just like I am. I've met other artists, writers, and musicians who are all pushing their own boundaries. It's inspiring to be around people who are chasing their dreams, even if they don't always have the easiest path. I've also learned to appreciate the little things more—the way the city never sleeps, the way the streets feel alive with possibility. It's not the same as the quiet, tight-knit neighborhood I grew up in, but this place has given me a chance to redefine what home means to me. It's not just a place on a map—it's where I'm learning to become who I want to be.

Going through the interview questions about my family and current neighborhood made me reflect on how much my life has changed, yet how much of my past still shapes who I am. Talking about my parents and my grandmother reminded me of the strength and sacrifices that built the foundation of my life. Even though I don't see my father as often as I'd like, and my relationship with him is sometimes strained, I know he cares in his own way. My grandmother, though, is the one who truly anchors me—her wisdom and love keep me grounded. As for my neighborhood, it's not perfect, but it feels like a place where I can finally belong. It's not just the safety or the diversity that I love; it's the sense of possibility, the feeling that I'm part of something bigger. I think that's what I'm really trying to build for myself—not just a life, but a community where I can create, grow, and support others the way I've been supported.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Lilliana Sierra: A typical week for me is pretty consistent, but there are definitely moments that make each day feel unique. I start most mornings around 7 or 8, depending on how late I stayed up working on art projects. I usually make coffee, sit by the window, and sketch for a bit before heading to the café. My shifts there are usually in the afternoons, so I have a few hours in the morning to myself. After work, I like to walk around the neighborhood, sometimes stopping by the local bookstore or grabbing a bite to eat at one of the small restaurants. On weekends, I try to dedicate more time to my art—whether it's painting, experimenting with digital design, or just brainstorming ideas. I also have a few days a week where I meet up with friends or go to open mic nights at the community center. It's not always easy balancing everything, but I find that structure helps me stay focused on what I'm trying to build. There are days when I feel like I'm spinning my wheels, but I remind myself that progress isn't always linear. I'm learning to be patient with myself, even when the path isn't clear.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Lilliana Sierra: I work part-time at a local café called 'Café Sol,' which is right near my apartment. I usually work three afternoons a week, from 2 p.m. to 6 p.m., and sometimes on weekends if they need extra help. The café is owned by a couple from Colombia, and they've been really supportive of me. I started there right after I came back from the summer program, and it's been a good place to keep my feet on the ground while I figure out what I want to do next. I love the energy of the place—it's always bustling with people, students, artists, and even some regulars who come in just to chat. I've learned a lot from working there, not just about coffee and customer service, but also about people. I've met so many interesting folks who come in, and sometimes they'll ask me about my art or my dreams, which is always encouraging. It's not a high-paying job, and I know it's not where I want to be forever, but it helps me pay the bills and gives me time to work on my own projects in the evenings and on the weekends.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Lilliana Sierra: Outside of work and my art, I also have a few responsibilities that keep me grounded. I help my grandmother with some errands a few times a week—grocery shopping, picking up prescriptions, that kind of thing. She's been my rock for as long as I can remember, and I want to make sure she's taken care of, even if I'm still figuring out my own path. I also try to keep up with my online courses in graphic design whenever I can. I enrolled in a few through a community college, and I take classes in the evenings after work. It's not always easy balancing everything—some days I feel like I'm juggling too many things at once—but I remind myself that every little step counts. I also try to stay active, even if it's just a short walk or a yoga video at home. It helps me clear my mind and stay focused on what I'm working toward. I think having these routines, even the small ones, helps me feel like I'm making progress, even when the bigger picture isn't always clear.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Lilliana Sierra: One of the biggest changes to my daily routine has been starting to take online classes in graphic design more consistently. I used to put them off because I was so busy with work and helping my grandmother, but I've realized that if I want to turn my art into something more, I need to commit to learning the technical side of design. I've been waking up a little earlier now, around 6:30 or 7, to get in a few hours of study before my shift at the café. It's been tough adjusting, especially since I'm still trying to balance everything, but I've started to see progress. I've even begun taking on small freelance projects through online platforms, which is exciting. It's not a lot of money, but it's a start. I think this change has helped me feel more in control of my future, even if it's still a little uncertain. It's like I'm finally taking the steps I've been dreaming about, and that gives me a sense of purpose I haven't felt in a long time.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Lilliana Sierra: I don't have children yet, but I often imagine what life would be like if I did. I think I'd want to give them the same kind of support and encouragement that I received from my grandmother and that teacher who believed in me. I'd want them to know that their dreams are valid, no matter where they come from. If they had a typical weekday during the school year, I imagine them waking up early, maybe with a breakfast of fresh fruit and toast, then heading off to school with a backpack full of books and art supplies. After school, I'd hope they'd have time to explore their interests—maybe join a club or take a class in something they're passionate about. I'd want them to feel safe, supported, and free to be themselves, just like I'm trying to build for myself now.

Going through the interview questions about my family and current neighborhood made me reflect on how much my life has changed, yet how much of my past still shapes who I am. Talking about my parents and my grandmother reminded me of the strength and sacrifices that built the foundation of my life. Even though I don't see my father as often as I'd like, and my relationship with him is sometimes strained, I know he cares in his own way. My grandmother, though, is the one who truly anchors me—her wisdom and love keep me grounded. As for my neighborhood, it's not perfect, but it feels like a place where I can finally belong. It's not just the safety or the diversity that I love; it's the sense of possibility, the feeling that I'm part of something bigger. I think that's what I'm really trying to build for myself—not just a life, but a community where I can create, grow, and support others the way I've been supported.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Lilliana Sierra: My health has been up and down, like most things in my life. I've always been pretty active as a kid, running around the neighborhood or sketching outside for hours, but things changed a bit after I came back from boarding school. I started gaining weight, probably from stress and not having the same energy to move around as much. I didn't take it seriously at first, but a few years ago, I got really sick with something that made me take a few weeks off work. It was the first time I really thought about how my lifestyle was affecting me. Since then, I've been trying to take better care of myself—eating more fruits and veggies, even if it's just a banana and some yogurt for breakfast, and trying to move my body more, even if it's just a short walk or a few yoga videos at home. I also started seeing a therapist a few months ago, which has been really helpful in dealing with some of the anxiety I've been carrying. It's not perfect, and there are still days when I feel like I'm not doing enough, but I'm learning that taking care of my health isn't just about being strong—it's about being present, and that matters more than I ever realized.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Lilliana Sierra: What makes it easy to stay healthy is knowing that even small changes can make a difference. Like when I started walking to work instead of taking the bus, or when I began eating more fruits and vegetables because I could afford them. Those little choices add up, and they remind me that I'm in control of my own well-being. What makes it hard, though, is the stress of trying to balance everything—work, school, helping my grandmother, and still finding time for myself. Sometimes, I feel like I'm running on empty, and that makes it harder to stick to a routine. I also struggle with the guilt of not being able to afford healthier food options or going to the gym regularly. But I'm learning that health isn't just about perfect habits—it's about showing up for yourself, even on the tough days, and doing what you can, even if it's not enough. That's what keeps me going.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Lilliana Sierra: In the past two years, I had a pretty bad flare-up of chronic back pain that I didn't realize I had. It started around the time I was taking on more freelance work and spending long hours hunched over my laptop or sketching. At first, I thought it was just stress, but it got to the point where I couldn't sit for more than an hour without pain radiating down my legs. I finally went to the doctor, and she said it was probably from poor posture and lack of movement over time. I was diagnosed with a mild herniated disc, which was a bit of a shock. It forced me to slow down and take better care of my body, even if it meant missing a few days of work or pushing back on some projects. It was hard, but it also made me realize how much I've been neglecting my health for so long. I started seeing a physical therapist, and I've been doing some exercises to strengthen my core and improve my posture. It's been a slow process, but I'm finally starting to feel better. That experience made me more aware of how my body is connected to everything else in my life—my work, my dreams, my family. I can't keep pushing through pain if I want to keep moving forward, and that's something I need to remember every day.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Lilliana Sierra: The back pain did make things harder, especially with the long hours I spend working on my art and at the café. There were days when I had to cancel shifts or push back on freelance projects because I couldn't sit through a full session without discomfort. It was frustrating because I felt like I was falling behind, and I didn't want to let my health stop me from moving forward. But at the same time, it forced me to slow down and really think about how I was living my life. I realized I was carrying so much on my shoulders—my family, my dreams, my responsibilities—and I wasn't taking time to take care of myself. That pain was a reminder that I can't keep pushing through without breaking. It also made me more aware of how my body is connected to everything else. If I'm not healthy, I can't be there for my grandmother, or for my art, or for the future I'm trying to build. So, even though it was tough, I think it was a necessary pause. It taught me that taking care of myself isn't a luxury—it's a foundation. And now, I'm trying to build that foundation stronger, so I can keep going without falling apart.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Lilliana Sierra: Over the past year, I've been feeling a mix of things—some days I feel like I'm finally starting to find my footing, and other days I feel like I'm just treading water. There's been a lot of growth, but also a lot of uncertainty. I've been working harder on my art, taking those online classes more seriously, and even landing a few small freelance projects, which has been really encouraging. It's given me a sense of purpose I haven't felt in a while. But there are still moments when I feel overwhelmed, especially when I think about how much I have to do and how little time I have. I've been trying to be kinder to myself, though, and I've started setting smaller goals for myself—like finishing a painting a week or dedicating an hour each day to studying. I think the biggest change has been in how I see myself. I used to feel like I was just surviving, but now I feel like I'm actually living, even if it's not always easy. I'm still figuring things out, but I'm starting to believe that I can build something meaningful for myself, and that gives me hope.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my daily routine has changed, especially with starting online classes in graphic design and taking my health more seriously. It's been a challenging adjustment, balancing work, school, and taking care of my grandmother, but I feel like I'm finally making progress. I used to think that my health wasn't something I could control, but now I see it as part of the foundation I need to build for myself. Even small changes, like waking up earlier or taking short walks, have made a difference. I also had to confront my chronic back pain, which forced me to slow down and realize that I can't keep pushing through without breaking. It was hard, but it also made me more aware of how my body is connected to everything else in my life. I'm still learning, but I'm starting to believe that I can create a life that's not just about survival, but about growth and purpose.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Lilliana Sierra: I think I've struggled with anxiety more than anything else, though I didn't always recognize it for what it was. There were times when I felt like I was constantly on edge, worrying about money, my future, and whether I was making the right choices. I used to feel like I had to be perfect—perfect at art, perfect at work, perfect at taking care of my grandmother. If I messed up, I'd spiral into self-doubt, thinking I wasn't good enough or that I'd end up just like my parents, stuck in the same cycle. It wasn't until I started seeing a therapist that I realized how much of that anxiety was tied to fear—fear of failure, fear of not being enough, fear of not having a plan. Now, I try to acknowledge those feelings without letting them control me. I've started journaling, and sometimes I write down my worries so I can look at them and say, 'Okay, this is real, but it doesn't have to define me.' It's not always easy, but I'm learning that it's okay to not have all the answers. What matters is that I keep showing up, even when I don't feel like it.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Lilliana Sierra: For my family, it's been a mix of pride and worry. My mother has always been my biggest supporter, but I can see the fear in her eyes when she worries about my future. She doesn't want me to struggle the way she did, and I know she's proud of me for taking these steps, even if she doesn't fully understand the path I'm on. My father, on the other hand, is more reserved. He doesn't say much, but I know he's watching me, waiting to see if I'll make it. He's never been one for words, but I can tell he's trying to be there for me in his own way. And my grandmother—she's the one who keeps everything together. She doesn't let the stress get to her, even when she's worried about her health or the bills. She always says, 'You're not alone, Lilliana. You have us.' That's what keeps me going. Even when I feel like I'm not enough, I know they believe in me, and that gives me strength to keep moving forward.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Lilliana Sierra: I wouldn't say religion or spirituality is something I actively practice, but I do believe in something bigger than myself—maybe not a higher power, but the idea that people, stories, and connections have a kind of sacredness to them. I grew up in a Protestant household, and I remember going to church with my grandmother, who always said that faith was about love and kindness. But as I got older, I started to feel like those words were more about what I was supposed to believe rather than what I actually felt. I don't think I need a religion to feel connected to something greater. For me, that connection comes through art, through the people I love, and through the moments when I feel like I'm part of something that matters. I think that's enough for me—knowing that I can leave something behind, even if it's just a painting or a story, that might touch someone else. That feels like its own kind of faith.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Lilliana Sierra: I use Instagram the most, mostly to share my art and see what other creators are up to. It's a way for me to stay connected with the creative community, even if I'm not always sure where I'm headed. I follow a lot of local artists, writers, and designers, and sometimes I'll get inspired by their work or even get feedback on my own pieces. I also use it to document my journey—posting little snippets of my day, my struggles, and the small victories. It's not always easy being honest online, but there's something freeing about sharing parts of myself with people who might relate. I don't use Facebook much anymore; I find it too overwhelming with all the news and politics. For me, social media is more about connection and creativity than staying up to date with the world. It's a place where I can feel seen, even if just by a few people, and that means a lot to me.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Lilliana Sierra: Honestly, I haven't really relied on social media for emotional or financial support, but there have been moments when it felt like the only place where I could be honest about how I was feeling. I remember a few months ago, when I was going through that really tough time with my back pain and feeling like I wasn't making progress, I posted a few photos of my artwork with captions that were more about frustration than inspiration. To my surprise, a few people reached out—some offered encouragement, others shared their own struggles with chronic pain or creative blocks. It wasn't a lot, but it was enough to remind me that I wasn't alone in feeling stuck. I think what I've learned is that social media isn't just about putting your best self out there—it's also about showing up as you are, even when you're not sure where you're going. It's not a substitute for real support, but sometimes it's the first step in finding it.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect on how much my health and mental well-being have shaped the past year of my life. Talking about my chronic back pain reminded me of how much I've been pushing through without really taking care of myself. It wasn't just about the physical discomfort—it was about realizing that I had been neglecting my body for so long, trying to chase dreams and responsibilities without giving myself the space to heal. Then, when I discussed my anxiety, it felt like I was finally giving voice to something I've carried in silence for years. I used to think I had to be perfect, that I had to prove I was more than the life I was born into. But now I see that anxiety isn't a weakness—it's a sign that I care, that I want more, that I'm afraid of failing. And when I talked about how my family feels about all of this, it reminded me that I'm not alone in this struggle. My mother's pride, my father's quiet support, and my grandmother's unwavering love—they all keep me going, even on the hardest days. I'm still learning how to balance everything, but I'm starting to believe that taking care of my health and my mind isn't just about survival—it's about building a life that's worth living.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Lilliana Sierra: In the past few months, I've noticed that my stress levels have actually gone down a bit, which is something I didn't expect. I think it's because I've started to accept that I can't control everything—my health, my finances, even my future. That doesn't mean I don't worry anymore, but I've learned to hold on to the things I can control, like my daily routine, my art, and the small moments of joy I find in the day. I've also started journaling more, which helps me process my emotions without bottling them up. When I feel overwhelmed, I write down what's on my mind, and sometimes I even draw my feelings out—like turning anxiety into a sketch or a color palette. It's not a perfect solution, but it gives me a way to release the pressure. I've also started talking more openly with my friends and even my therapist about how I'm feeling, which has made a big difference. I used to think I had to carry everything on my own, but now I see that asking for help isn't a weakness—it's a way of staying grounded when the world feels too heavy.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Lilliana Sierra: Last month, my biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and my grandmother's medications. Rent takes up the largest chunk of my paycheck—about $1,200 a month for this small apartment. Groceries are another big one, especially since I try to eat healthily even on a tight budget. I also have to set aside money for my grandmother's prescriptions, which can be expensive sometimes. I'm lucky that my parents help out when they can, but I still have to stretch every dollar. I also pay for my online classes and art supplies, which I try to keep as minimal as possible. I've been trying to track my spending more carefully, using a simple spreadsheet to make sure I don't go over my limit. It's not easy, but I've learned that even small savings—like buying in bulk or using coupons—can add up. I know it's not much, but I'm proud of the fact that I'm managing to keep things afloat while still working toward my goals.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Lilliana Sierra: To be honest, the amount we spent last month was a bit higher than usual, mostly because I had to cover some unexpected medical costs related to my back pain. I usually spend around $1,500 to $1,600 a month, but last month it came to closer to $1,800. Rent is still the biggest part—$1,200—but then I had to pay for a few additional therapy sessions, some new art supplies I couldn't do without, and a few extra groceries because I was skipping meals more than I should have. It's not ideal, but I've learned to be flexible with my budget. I try to set aside a little each week for emergencies, even if it's just a few dollars. It's not much, but it helps me feel more in control. I also make sure to prioritize what's most important—my grandmother's medications, my online classes, and the basics like food and shelter. The rest, I try to do without or find creative ways to stretch. It's a tightrope walk, but I'm learning to walk it without falling.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Lilliana Sierra: We rent our home. It's a small apartment in a building that's been around for a while, and while it's not the most luxurious place, it's got character—old wood floors, a little courtyard in the back where I sometimes sketch when I can. Renting is the only option for now, especially with the way things are financially. I know I could save more if I moved somewhere cheaper, but this place feels like a step toward something more stable. It's not just about the money; it's about being close to the café, to the community center where I take my art classes, and to the people who keep me going. I don't know when we'll be ready to buy a home, but for now, this place is our foundation, and I'm grateful for that.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Lilliana Sierra: Over the past year, my bills have definitely fluctuated, especially with the seasons and the different things that come up. In the summer, for example, the electricity bill tends to be higher because we use the air conditioning more, and I remember last July it was almost $150, which was a bit of a shock. Then there's the winter, when the heating kicks in, but honestly, Miami doesn't get that cold, so it's not as bad. Holidays are another thing—during the holidays, I usually spend a little more on groceries, especially if there's a family gathering or if I want to treat myself to something small. Last December, I had to buy a new set of winter clothes for my grandmother, which wasn't cheap, and that added to the expenses. Then there are the unexpected things, like when my laptop broke down a few months ago and I had to replace it, or when I had to pay for an extra week of therapy because my insurance coverage ran out. It's not always easy keeping track of it all, but I've started setting aside a little extra each month for these kinds of surprises. I know it's not much, but it helps me feel more prepared when things come up.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how much my family's support and my use of social media have shaped my emotional well-being. Talking about how my family feels about my struggles reminded me that even though I sometimes feel like I'm carrying everything on my own, I'm not alone. My mother's pride, my father's quiet belief in me, and my grandmother's unwavering love are the things that keep me going, even on the hardest days. It also made me think about how I use social media—not just as a platform for my art, but as a way to connect with others who might be going through similar things. I used to be afraid of being vulnerable online, but now I see it as a way to find community and support, even if it's just a few kind words or a shared experience. It's not a perfect solution, but it's a start, and that's something I can be grateful for.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Lilliana Sierra: I don't have a traditional savings account, but I do save in small, practical ways. For example, I set aside a few dollars from each paycheck into a separate jar labeled 'emergency fund,' even if it's just $10 or $20. It's not much, but it gives me a sense of control when everything else feels so uncertain. I also try to save on things I can live without—like buying secondhand art supplies or waiting for sales on groceries. Sometimes, I'll trade or barter with friends for things I need, like a sketchbook or a new brush. I know it's not the same as having a big savings account, but it's something. I used to think saving was only for people who had extra money, but now I see it as a way to build something, even if it's just a little at a time. It's not perfect, but it's a start, and that's what matters.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Lilliana Sierra: For me, saving has mostly been about preparing for the unexpected—like medical bills, a broken laptop, or a sudden increase in rent. I don't have big dreams of buying a house or traveling right now; I'm more focused on building a stable foundation so I can keep supporting my grandmother and working toward my art. I know it sounds small, but every little bit I save feels like a step forward. I used to think saving was something for people with more money, but now I see it as a way to take control of my life, even in tiny ways. It's not about having a lot—it's about being ready for whatever comes next, even if it's just a few dollars in that jar.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Lilliana Sierra: My occupation right now is a mix of things—part-time work at the café, online graphic design courses, and freelance art projects when I can find them. The most important part of my job at the café is connecting with people, even if it's just through a coffee order or a friendly chat. It's not just about making drinks; it's about being present, listening, and sometimes even offering a bit of encouragement when someone seems down. That's something I didn't expect to learn from a job, but it's become one of the most rewarding parts. As for the graphic design courses, the most important activities are practicing the technical skills—like learning how to use design software, understanding color theory, and building a portfolio that reflects who I am as an artist. It's challenging because I'm learning so much on my own, but it's also empowering. I know I'm not there yet, but every project I complete feels like a step closer to turning my passion into something I can actually do for a living.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Lilliana Sierra: I usually work around 20 to 25 hours a week, depending on how busy the café gets and how many freelance projects I have going on. Some weeks, I'll work three afternoons at the café and maybe a few hours on the weekends if they need extra help. Then there are the days I spend on my online classes or working on art commissions. It's not a lot, but it's enough to keep me moving forward. I used to feel like I wasn't doing enough, like I was just scraping by, but now I see it as a balance—between work, learning, and taking care of my grandmother. It's not perfect, but it's what I can manage right now, and I'm learning to be okay with that.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Lilliana Sierra: Yes, I actually had a few different jobs and side projects going on at the same time, especially when I was trying to figure out what I wanted to do with my art. Besides working at the café, I used to do small freelance illustration gigs through online platforms, mostly for local businesses or independent artists who needed someone to design logos or social media graphics. I also volunteered at a community art space on weekends, helping organize events and teaching kids basic drawing techniques. It was exhausting at times, juggling all of that with my online classes and taking care of my grandmother, but it taught me a lot about time management and what I was willing to sacrifice for my goals. I think that period was really important for me—it showed me that I could be creative and productive even when I didn't have a clear path ahead. It also made me realize that I needed to be more strategic about how I spent my time, which is why I've been trying to focus more on the things that actually matter to my long-term growth.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much my stress levels, emotional coping strategies, and financial situation have shaped my recent experiences. Talking about my stress reminded me that I've been learning to accept that I can't control everything, and that has helped me focus more on what I can manage—like my daily routine, my art, and the small joys in life. It also made me realize how important it is to have emotional outlets, like journaling or talking to friends and my therapist. I used to think I had to carry everything on my own, but now I see that asking for help is a strength, not a weakness. When it came to discussing my finances, it was humbling to admit how tight things are, but it also gave me a sense of pride in knowing I'm managing to keep things afloat while still working toward my goals. It reminded me that even small savings and careful budgeting matter, and that I'm not just surviving—I'm building something for myself, one step at a time.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Lilliana Sierra: In total, my household made about $2,400 last month, which includes my part-time income from the café, a few freelance design gigs, and some small stipends from online courses I've completed. It's not a lot, but it's enough to cover rent, groceries, my grandmother's medications, and a few essentials. I know it's not stable yet, and there are months when I have to stretch that money further, especially if I have unexpected expenses or if my freelance work slows down. But I'm trying to be more intentional with how I spend and save, even if it's just a few dollars at a time. I think what matters most is that I'm not just surviving—I'm building something, even if it's slow and steady.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Lilliana Sierra: I've been working at Café Sol for almost three years now, and while it's not the most glamorous job, it's been a steady part of my life. The benefits aren't traditional—there's no health insurance or paid vacation days, but the owners are really supportive in other ways. They let me take time off when I need to, especially when I was dealing with my back pain, and they've been patient with me as I've tried to balance work with my online classes and art projects. What I appreciate most is the sense of community there. The café is like a little hub for people in the neighborhood—students, artists, musicians, everyone comes in and shares a little piece of themselves. It's not just about making coffee; it's about being part of something that feels alive and real. I know I'm not going to stay there forever, but for now, it's a place where I can keep learning, keep growing, and keep showing up for the people who come through the door.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Lilliana Sierra: My relationships at work are pretty warm and supportive, even if it's not a traditional office environment. The owners of the café, Maria and Carlos, are like family to me. They've been nothing but kind, even when I was struggling with my back pain and had to take extra days off. They never made me feel like I was a burden, which meant a lot when I was already feeling like I wasn't doing enough. As for my coworkers, we all have our own stories, our own reasons for being there, and we've built this kind of unspoken bond. We laugh a lot, we share food, and sometimes we just sit and talk about our lives. I think that's what makes the café more than just a job—it's a place where I feel seen, even if just for a few hours a day. I don't have a manager in the traditional sense, but Maria is the one who oversees the day-to-day, and she's always checking in on me, making sure I'm okay. I think that kind of care is rare, and I'm really grateful for it.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Lilliana Sierra: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but it's not always the same from week to week. I usually work three afternoons a week, from 2 p.m. to 6 p.m., and sometimes I pick up an extra shift on the weekends if they need help. The owners are flexible, so if I have an appointment or need to take a day off for something like therapy or family, they let me adjust my hours. That flexibility is something I really appreciate, especially since I'm juggling school and taking care of my grandmother. It's not always easy to plan ahead, but knowing that I can shift my schedule a bit when I need to helps me feel more in control of my time. I think that kind of understanding from my coworkers and the owners makes a big difference—it shows that they see me as more than just someone who makes coffee. They see me as someone who's trying to build a life, and that means a lot.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Lilliana Sierra: Overall, I feel like my financial situation is a constant balancing act, but I'm trying not to see it as a burden. It's not easy, and there are days when I worry about whether I'm doing enough or if I'll ever be able to break free from this cycle. But I also know that I'm not just surviving—I'm learning, growing, and building something for myself and my grandmother. I used to think that financial stability was the only way to feel secure, but now I see that it's about more than just money. It's about having a plan, even if it's small, and being willing to take risks when the time is right. I know I'm not there yet, but I'm proud of the fact that I'm still moving forward, even if it's one step at a time.

Going through the interview questions from 36 to 40 made me reflect on how much my financial situation and work life have shaped my recent experiences. Talking about how my bills fluctuate reminded me of the unpredictability of life, especially when you're trying to balance work, school, and family responsibilities. It's not always easy keeping track of everything, but I've learned to be more prepared for the unexpected, even if it's just a few dollars set aside each month. When I discussed my occupation and how many hours I work, it made me realize how much I've grown in understanding the value of time and effort, even if my income isn't huge. I used to feel like I wasn't doing enough, but now I see that every hour I spend at the café, every class I take, and every project I complete is a step toward something bigger. It's not about having a lot—it's about being intentional with what I have and using it to build a future that feels meaningful, even if it's slow and steady.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Lilliana Sierra: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up, though their jobs were never the same from year to year. My dad worked as a mechanic at the same auto shop in Miami for over twenty years, and even though he never had the chance to go to college, he was always trying to make sure we had what we needed. My mom worked cleaning offices, sometimes for the same company, sometimes for different ones, depending on what was available. They both worked hard, but it wasn't enough to lift us out of the struggles we faced. I remember watching them worry about bills, about whether they'd be able to afford groceries or medicine, and I think that's what made me want to do something different for myself. I didn't want to end up in the same cycle they were in, always working just to keep up. That's why I started focusing on my art, why I took that summer program, and why I keep pushing forward even when things are tough. I know they didn't have the same opportunities I have now, but I also know they gave me the strength to believe that I could build something better.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Lilliana Sierra: My dad worked as a mechanic, mostly at a small auto shop in our neighborhood. His most important duties were fixing cars, doing oil changes, and replacing parts when needed. He was really good at what he did, but he never had the chance to go to college or get any formal training beyond high school. He always said that if you had a wrench and a little knowledge, you could fix anything. My mom worked cleaning offices—sometimes for the same company for years, other times for different ones depending on what was available. Her most important activities were making sure the offices were spotless, organizing files, and keeping everything running smoothly. She was always the kind of person who could make a space feel like home, even if it was just for a few hours a day. Both of them worked hard, but it wasn't enough to lift us out of the struggles we faced. I remember watching them worry about bills, about whether they'd be able to afford groceries or medicine, and I think that's what made me want to do something different for myself. I didn't want to end up in the same cycle they were in, always working just to keep up. That's why I started focusing on my art, why I took that summer program, and why I keep pushing forward even when things are tough. I know they didn't have the same opportunities I have now, but I also know they gave me the strength to believe that I could build something better.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Lilliana Sierra: My dad worked at a small auto shop owned by a guy named Mr. Rivera, who had been in the business for over thirty years. It was a family-run place, and most of the mechanics there had been working there for decades. They fixed everything from cars to trucks, and sometimes even did some minor repairs on motorcycles. It was a tough job, especially in the heat of Miami, but my dad always said he loved the challenge of figuring out what was wrong with a car and making it run again. My mom worked for a cleaning company that serviced different office buildings in the city. She'd start her day early, sometimes before 6 a.m., and spend the whole day cleaning, organizing, and making sure the offices were ready for the day. She always said that her job wasn't just about cleaning—it was about making people feel comfortable in their workspaces. I remember her coming home tired, but also proud, like she had made a difference in some small way. Both of them worked hard, but it wasn't enough to lift us out of the struggles we faced. I remember watching them worry about bills, about whether they'd be able to afford groceries or medicine, and I think that's what made me want to do something different for myself. I didn't want to end up in the same cycle they were in, always working just to keep up. That's why I started focusing on my art, why I took that summer program, and why I keep pushing forward even when things are tough. I know they didn't have the same opportunities I have now, but I also know they gave me the strength to believe that I could build something better.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Lilliana Sierra: I hope that in a few years, I'm not just surviving but truly thriving—living a life where my art isn't just a passion but a way to support myself and the people I love. I want to be in a place where I can afford to rent a space of my own, not just a small apartment, but somewhere that feels like a studio and a home. I want to be able to take my time with my work, to create without the constant pressure of making ends meet. I also hope that I'm not just building a career for myself, but that I'm helping others, maybe by teaching or mentoring young artists who feel the same way I did when I was 16—lost, unsure, but full of potential. I want to be someone who can look back and say, 'I didn't just make it—I helped others make it too.' And most of all, I want to be there for my grandmother, to make sure she's comfortable and happy, and to show her that the dreams she always believed in for me are finally becoming real.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Lilliana Sierra: What I value the most in my life is connection—real, meaningful connection. It's not just about family or friends, though they're definitely a big part of it. It's about feeling seen, understood, and supported, even when life feels heavy. I value the moments when someone looks at my art and sees something in it that resonates with them, or when a friend listens to me without judgment. I value the way my grandmother still finds joy in the simplest things, like the smell of her cooking or the sound of her stories. I value the fact that I'm still learning, still growing, even when it's slow. I think what I value most is the belief that I can create something meaningful out of the struggles I've faced, and that I can pass that belief on to others. It's not always easy, but it's what keeps me going.

Going through the interview questions from 41 to 45 made me reflect on how much my work life and financial situation have shaped my recent experiences. Talking about my income and household earnings reminded me of the tightrope I walk between survival and growth, and how every dollar I earn feels like a step toward something bigger. It also made me think about how grateful I am for the support I've received at Café Sol—not just for the job itself, but for the understanding and flexibility the owners have shown me. I used to feel like I was just scraping by, but now I see that my work, even if it's not perfect, is part of a larger journey. It's not just about making ends meet—it's about building a foundation, even if it's small, and knowing that I'm not alone in this effort.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been like peeling back the layers of who I am, revealing the struggles, the support, and the quiet strength that has shaped me. It reminded me of how far I've come—from a quiet girl in a small Miami apartment, unsure of her future, to someone who is now actively building a life through art, education, and community. I never imagined I'd be here, standing on the edge of something new, still learning, still growing. It also made me reflect on the people who have been there for me—the teacher who saw my potential, the artist who gave me supplies, my mother who always believed in me, and my grandmother, who has been the heart of our family. Their support has been the foundation of everything I've achieved. This interview made me realize that my story isn't just about survival; it's about resilience, about finding purpose in the face of uncertainty, and about believing in the possibility of change. I may not have all the answers yet, but I know I'm on the right path, and that gives me hope for the future.
